column8: Notes
attends Frères Bretons de l'Instruction Chrétienne; attends Pinchinat High School and Pétion High School
moves w/mother, father, four brothers and sisters
column11: Étincelles (Imprimerie de l'État 1945); Gerbes de Sang (Imprimerie de l'État 1946)
column12: Dewitt Peters, founder of the Centre d'Art) is his English professor in highschool; Nicolás Guillén (1942) invited to PAP by Jacques Roumain; attends Alejo Carpentier's lecture (1943); attends Aimé Césaire's seminar May-Dec 1944); meets Jacques Stephen Alexis, Theodore Baker, Gérald Bloncourt, Gérard Chenet (co-editors of La Ruche), L'aurore Saint-Juste

column8: returns to live with his maternal grandmother (dispersal of brothers and sisters among different family members, mother returns to PAP) following the death of his father in 1936; attends Frères de l'Instruction Chrétien and then Lycée Pinchinat; vacations Meyer beach, "Echos de la guerre d'Espagne et de la guerre mondiale."

column7:
BFM RD-V D1/06

"Départ de Mr René Depestre," Le Nouvelliste (10/15/46): 1
column8: attends lycée Pétion, founds journal La Ruche; takes classes with Dewitt Peters; meets Nicolás Guillén (1942); invited to PAP by Jacques Roumain; attends Alejo Carpentier's lecture (1943); attends Aimé Césaire's seminar (May-Dec 1944); meets Jacques Stephen Alexis, Theodore Baker, Gérald Bloncourt, Gérard Chenet (co-editors of La Ruche); meets L'Aurore Saint-Juste
column10: tho according to J Jonnaissaint, a dedication to his father in a copy of Gerbe de sang puts RD in PaP till November 1946

column8: arrives from Port-au-Prince (stays at Pennsylvania Hotel); departs to Cherbourg via ship L'Île de France
arrives via ship from New York; continues to Paris, is picked up by Aimé Césaire
connects w/Gérald Bloncourt, Jacques Stephen Alexis, Edouard Glissant; spends time w/Francis Joachim Roy, members of French intelligentsia etc; enrolls at Sciences Politiques, La Sorbonne
attends International Festival of Students and Youth on behalf of World Federation of Democratic Youth
spends summer laying rail tracks from Samac to Sarajevo,Yugoslavia
joins the "Group of Young Poets" created by Elsa Triolet January 14, 1950 (lasts until 1956); attends Sorbonne lecture by Tristan Tzara April 11, 1947; joins PCF
resides at Chateau de Dobris
column12: Ilya Ehrenbourg – learns things "of capital importance" regarding Stalinist perversion of communism across Europe

column8: attends Third World Festival of Youth and Students for Peace; encounters Nicolàs Guillén at festival
column10: Cuba journal 9/11/1965 mistakenly says he was there summer 1952
column12: Turkish poet Nazim Hikmet; Anna Seghers, Diego Rivera, Georg Lukács, etc

column8: is expelled for criticism of Stalinist purges
awaits visa from the Cuban embassy and embarks on the Francesco Morosini (stops in Lisbon, Naples, Santa Cruz de Tenerife, la Guaira); learns of Batista's coup onboard ship March 10
is invited by Guillén; arrested by Fulgencio Batista; imprisoned for two months; expelled
disembarks from the Francesco Morosini
attends Maison de la pensée française; connects w/Aragon and Bloncourt; is discovered walking on Pont Saint Michel and expelled from France
attends World Peace Council 12/12-12/19
column10: World Peace Council (founded by Cominform in 1950 to combat US "warmongering" and nuclearization)

column8: passes through on the invitation of painter Renato Guttuso; stays in the Alcron Hotel
column10: [leaves from here to Brazil before heading to Chile: figure out these dates]
column12: Pierre Courtade, who helps him understand that the failures of men of the Party are not the failures of the Bolshevik communist ideals

column7: Depestre archive, BFM Limoges (programme del Congreso Continental de Cultura)
column8: organizes Congreso Continental de la Cultura w/Pablo Neruda and Jorge Amado (April 6-May 2, 1953)
column12: Salvador Allende; Manuel Rojas; Angel Cruchaga Santa Marîa, Jorge Edwards, Benjamin Subercaseaux, Nicanor Parra, Enrique Lihn, Nicolás Guillén, Jorge amada, Diego Rivera

column8: lives in Acassusso and Olivos (2 months); meets – his portraitist Antonio Berni; ; takes the boat Anna C to Brazil (stopover in Montevideo)
column12: Victoria and Silvina Ocampo, editors of literary magazine Sur

column7: Depestre archive, BFM Limoges, dated poem "Lettre à ma mère"
column8: engages as militant in Brazilian Communist Party; writes under the name "Walter Miranda"; returns to Paris on boat the Bretagne
column10: Depestre archive, BFM Limoges: multiple letters regarding possible work in Bulgaria if/when he is expelled from Brazil; dated poem "Lettre à ma mère"
column11: "Lettre à Charles Dobzynski" in Les lettres françaises

column4: letters dated 1955-08-20 to mother; 1955-10-24 and letter dated 1955-12-03 from Charles Dobzynski
column8: receives a visa to enter France thanks to Léopold Sedar Senghor's intervention (actually arrives summer 1955 according to article "Alioune Diop")
column10: letter dated 1955-10-24 indicating surprise at learning of RD's move to Paris; letter dated 1955-12-03 from Charles Dobzynski asking him to come over for a party

column8: resides at Moulin d'Andé w/Richard Wright, Maurice Pons, Suzanne Lipinska
participates in First International Conference of Negro Writers and Artists organized by Présence Africaine
resides at Moulin d'Andé w/Richard Wright, Maurice Pons, Suzanne Lipinska

participates in First International Conference of Negro Writers and Artists organized by Présence Africaine

leaves for Haiti at the end of November aboard the Cristallina (boards in Anvers, stops in Portugal, Puerto Rico)
is invited by François Duvalier to return from exile and assume post of Foreign Affairs Minister; debates with JS Alexis in Le Nouvelliste (1958)

is invited to Cuba by Che Guevara on Guillén's recommendation; meeting with Guevara at Tarara (accompanied by Guillén); assumes role in the National Press; serves as Minister of Exterior Relations, as journalist for Revolución and Hoy, as broadcaster on Radio Cuba
column12: C.L.R. James; Mario Vargas Llosa, Julio Cortazar

column8: is sent to USSR and Asia as correspondent for Revolución
meets with Mao Tse-tung and Chou En-lai
Jacques Stephen Alexis arrives to prepare invasion of Haiti; meets w/Alexis to discuss reconciling 2 factions of Haitian communism
meets with Ho Chi Minh
is mobilized in the 197th battalion for training in the El Caribe military camp on the northern coast during Bay of Pigs conflict

column7: "Des patriotes haïtiens réunis à Moscou" BFM RD-V D1/06
column8: returns as correspondent for Revolución

column11: Mineral negro (1962); Journal d'un animal marin (Seghers 1964)

column10: "Le 20 juillet je me trouvais loin de Cuba, à Moscou, d'où j'avais écrit à ma mère."
"Quelques jours plus tard, de Paris, je lui ai adressé une nouvelle lettre"

column8: participates in Tricontinental (January 1965)
column11: "Lettre de Cuba" Présence Africaine (1965); "El que no tiene de Congo..." (1965); "Aventuras de la Negritud" (1967); Cantate d'octobre à Che Guevara (1968); Un arc-en-ciel pour l'Occident chrétien (1971); Le mât de cocagne (1975)

column8: meets Sartre

participates in Segundo Congreso Latinoamericano de Escritores: meets Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Asturias – sees Carpentier, Guillen, Retamar, (Cuban delegation), Che Guevara; interview with Régis Debray on Radio Havana Cuba
organizes Cultural Congress of Havana January 4-11, 1968; interviews Césaire, sees Leiris, Faye, "toute l'imntelloigentsia de gauche"; sees friend Mario de Andrade, meets Amilcar Cabral
covers First Panafrican Cultural Congress of Algers (July 21-31) as journalist for Granma; sees Cabral, Andrade; meets Henri Lopès, Amadou M'Bow
gives lecture on feminism for "International Day of Women" at Ministry of Sugar (March 7, 1973)
column10: gives lecture on feminism for "International Day of Women" to the female personnel of the Minstry of Sugar (March 7, 1973)
column11: Pour la révolution pour la poésie (Leméac 1974)

column8: attends Rencontre Internationals des Écrivains du Québec; "revoit avec plaisir Edouard Glissant; reconnects w/Haitian writers Laraque, Fouché, Bélance, Davertige; meets w/publishers re: Alléluia

pens "Lettre à Claude Roy" 1975-12-07 (Rage de vivre 258); gives lecture on feminism for "International Day of Women" (August 1975)

participates in Casa de las Americas conference – in attendance: Glissant, Phelps, Suzy Castor, Daniel Boukman, D.Scott

participates in International Smeinar against Apartheid organized by a special commission of the United Nations (May 1976); meets Derek Walcott and others at the Manlys
column10: gives lecture on feminism for "International Day of Women" to the female personnel of the Minstry of Sugar (March 7, 1973)

column8: teaches at Mona, University of the West Indies; attends Carifesta (July 23 - August 2, 1976)
pens "Lettre à Claude Roy" 1975-12-07 (Rage de vivre 258)
attends Carifesta (July 23 - August 2, 1976); attends gathering at Manley's home where encounters Derek Walcott, Edouard Glissant, Pable Retamar, C.L.R. James; encounters Juan Almeida Bosque
attends Second Congress of Cuban Writers and Artists (October 10-13, 1977); holds interview w/Jean Jonassaint (July 1978)

column11: Le mât de Cocagne (Gallimard 1979); En état de poésie (Éditeurs français réunis 1980); Bonjour et adieu à la négritude (Laffont 1980, 1989)

column8: UNESCO General Conference 21st session

column10: attends Congress of Pen Club as representative of UNESCO

column8: Couffon
column10: attends 8th World Congress of Poets presided over by Senghor as representative of UNESCO

column11: Au matin de la négritude (Euroediteur 1990); Journal d'un animal marin Gallimard 1990)

attends three-day program of visits, speeches, exhibitions in Jacmel
